poetic_form.description: The Sienna Mother is a solemn poetic form intended to amuse the audience, originating in The Tombs-Roads of Equivalence. The rules of the form are applied by poets to produce individual poems which can be recited. The poem is divided into two distinct quatrains. A form of parallelism is common throughout the poem, in that certain lines often share an underlying meaning. Each line has five feet with an accent pattern of unstressed-stressed (qualitative iambic pentameter). [B]The first part concerns the past. The fourth line of the quatrain must expand the idea of the first line. [B]The second part concerns the future. The fourth line of the quatrain must expand the idea of the first line.

The second line has five feet with an accent pattern of stressed-unstressed (qualitative trochaic pentameter). The third line has six feet with an accent pattern of stressed-unstressed (qualitative trochaic hexameter). The fourth line has seven feet with an accent pattern of stressed-unstressed (qualitative trochaic heptameter). The fifth line has four feet with an accent pattern of stressed-unstressed (qualitative trochaic tetrameter).
